trial_identification.studytitle: Does a 6-week program of intensive balance training improve the abiility of people with spinal cord injuries to perform functional tasks.
trial_identification.scientifictitle: Does a 6-week program of intensive balance training improve the abiility of people with spinal cord injuries to perform functional tasks.

interventions.interventions: Subjects will be randomly allocated to either a treatment or control group. The treatment group will exercise with a research physiotherapist for 60-minutes, 3 days a week for 6 weeks. The 60 minutes will be spent practicing particular tasks whilst seated. At the beginning and end of the 6-week period the subjects ability to sit balanced will be assessed.
interventions.comparator: The control group will receive no intervention for the 6 week period.

primaryOutcome.outcome: Canadian Occupational Performance Measure (COPM) - performance component

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Canadian Occupational Performance Measure (COPM) - importance and satisfaction components
Alternating Reach Test in supported and unsupported conditions
Upper Body Sway in anteroposterior and lateral directions
Self perception rating of balance when holding on, not holding on and fear of falling
Seated Reach Distance 45 degrees to right

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: Spinal cord injury between T1 and T12 (ASIA A, B or C with no greater than a total motor score of 5 for each lower limb); injury at least one year prior to inclusion in the study.
eligibility.exclusivecriteria: Pain or spasm affecting the ability to sit unsupported; pressure areas on the sacrum or ishial tuberosities.

trial_design.sequence: Simple randomisation using a randomization table created by computer software

ethicsAndSummary.summary: The primary purpose of this study is to determine the most effective way of improving the ability of people with spinal cord injuries to balance and sit unsupported. We hope to learn whether an intensive 6-week balance-training program improves the ability of people with established spinal cord injuries to balance and perform functional tasks.
